text: 8) while it's true that if everything is going amazing well a high burn rate won't hurt much
column4: most startups go through a trough of sorrow

text: 7) anyway
column4: founders would do well to remember that having an almost comically low burn in the early days work more often than the opposite

text: 6) founders seem to think "well we need money and the press loves us
column4: so we'll be able to raise more for sure"

text: 5) this meets cold reality when companies try to raise money again w/little traction and a $150k a month burn rate--often means death
4) and seed money is so easy to raise in the current environment that founders assume they can just raise more money whenever they want
3) but every small increase in burn ramps up the company's willingness to spend in subtle ways
2) it ends up being especially bad for startups where either the founders need big salaries or are non-technical and need to hire right away
1) "keep your burn rate very low" is one of those unteachable lessons for early-stage startups
